revision.text:
[[Environmental engineering|Environmental engineers]] conduct hazardous-waste management studies to evaluate the significance of such hazards, advise on treatment and containment, and develop regulations to prevent mishaps. Environmental engineers also design municipal water supply and industrial wastewater treatment systems as well as address local and worldwide environmental issues such as the effects of [[acid rain]], [[global warming]], [[ozone depletion]], [[water pollution]] and [[air pollution]] from automobile exhausts and industrial sources.
==List of notable environmental engineers==
* [[G. D. Agrawal]] * [[Braden Allenby]] * [[Ashraf Choudhary]] * [[Marc Edwards (civil engineering professor)|Marc Edwards]], civil engineering professor * [[Robert A. Gearheart]] * [[Alfred Stowell Jones]] * [[Sudhakar Kesavan]] * [[Joseph Lstiburek]] * [[Daniel Oerther]] * [[George Pinder]] * [[Ellen Swallow Richards]], known as the first female environmental engineer * [[Daniel A. Vallero]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{unsourced|date=December 2017}}
[[Category:Systems ecologists| ]] [[Category:Lists of environmental topics|Environmental engineers]] [[Category:Lists of engineers|Environmental engineers]] [[Category:Environmental engineers]]

page.title: List of longest prison sentences served

revision.comment: /* Prisoners who served more than sixty years */
revision.text:
This is a list of '''longest prison sentences served''' by a single person, worldwide, without a period of freedom followed by a second conviction. These cases rarely coincide with the [[list of longest prison sentences|longest prison sentences]] given, because some countries have laws that don't allow sentences without [[parole]] or for convicts to remain in prison beyond a given number of years (regardless of their original conviction). {{legend2|#5CFF67|This color indicates cases where imprisonment is still ongoing|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ==Prisoners who served more than sixty years== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- | Charles Fossard | 1903 | 1974 | 70 years, 303 days | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | Homeless [[French Australian]] recluded in the [[J Ward|J Ward mental asylum]] in [[Ararat, Victoria]] after murdering an elderly man and stealing his boots. Died while still incarcerated at the age of 92.http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/9812376 |- | [[Paul Geidel|Paul Geidel Jr.]] | 1911 | 1980 | 68 years, 245 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest-serving [[incarceration in the United States|prison inmate in the United States]] whose sentence ended in release. Incarcerated from 1911, aged 17 and released 1980 at 86. He died in a nursing home in 1987, aged 93. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Francis Clifford Smith | 7 June 1950 | ongoing | {{ayd|1950|6|7}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Oldest prisoner in the United States. Sentenced to death for the murder of a nightwatchman during a robbery at a yacht club in July 1949, his sentence was commuted to life in prison in 1954, only two hours before his scheduled execution. |- | Johnson Van Dyke Grigsby | 1908 | 1974 | 66 years, 123 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to life in prison for murder, he was denied parole 69 times before he was released at age 89. Returned to prison voluntarily, citing difficulty finding a job, but left again in 1976. Died in 1987, aged 101. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | John Phillips | 17 July 1952 | ongoing | {{ayd|1952|7|17}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[North Carolina]]. Convicted for the rape of a five-year-old girl.{{cite web|url=http://bailbondcity.com/north_carolina/ncdoc-inmate-PHILLIPS/0322466|title=PHILLIPS, JOHN PHILLIPS Inmate 0322466: North Carolina Prisons (DOC)|publisher=}} |- | [[William Heirens]] | 1946 | 2012 | 65 years, 181 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Known as the "Lipstick Killer". Reputed to be the longest surviving prisoner in [[Chicago]]. Died in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Joseph Ligon | 1953 | ongoing | {{ayd|1953|12|18}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | The oldest juvenile lifer in the U.S., Ligon at age 15 was sentenced to life without parole for murder, a mandatory sentence at the time.{{Cite news|url=https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2017/05/17/nations-oldest-juvenile-lifer-refuses-parole-will-appeal-new-sentence/|title=Nation’s Oldest Juvenile Lifer Refuses Parole, Will Appeal New Sentence|date=2017-05-17|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en}} Ligon first rejected a resentencing and parole offer in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/20161029_Juvenile_lifer__78__rejects_deal_for_parole___His_view_is__He_s_been_in_long_enough_.html|title=Juvenile lifer, 79, rejects deal for parole. 'His view is: He's been in long enough'|publisher=}} Ligon was again resentenced in 2017 and immediately eligible for parole but refused it, pending his appeal. Ligon contends that he should be resentenced to "time served" and released, so that can cut all ties to the justice system. |- | Clarence Marshall | 1950 | 2015 | 64 years, 70 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest-serving prisoner in [[Michigan]]. Sentenced to life in prison on one count of armed robbery and another of unarmed assault "with intent to rob and steal". Paroled. |- | [[Richard Honeck]] | 1899 | 1963 | 64 years, 44 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Aged 22, Honeck was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of a former school friend. He was paroled after 63 years and one month. He died in 1976, aged 97. |- | Howard Christensen | 1937 | 2001 | 64 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to life without parole for the murder of a teacher in 1937, when he was 16, along with a 17-year-old accomplice who hanged himself in prison in 1943. His sentence was commuted to 200 years in the mid-1970s. Died in 2003, aged 82. |- | Charles Edret Ford | 1952 | 2016 | 64 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Prisoner incarcerated for the longest time who was found to be innocent on retrial, and the longest serving prisoner in [[Maryland]]. Ford, a black man, was convicted for murder by an all-white jury in 1952, when he was 20, and again for an assault in 1975 supposedly committed while he was on parole. The second victim identified a different man as her attacker but the judge argued that both men looked alike enough. Ford, at the time the only person present at his first conviction who was still alive, was granted retrials in 2015 for both charges because he had not been informed of his right to appeal the sentences. He was found innocent of both and released to a nursing home.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebaynet.com/articles/0316/manfreeatlastafter64yearsinprison.html|title=Man free at last after 64 years in prison|publisher=}} |- | Oliver Terpening | 1947 | 2010 | 63 years, 125 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Killed a school friend and three young girls and attempted to rape another girl because he wanted to know how it felt to kill somebody. He found the experience disappointing. Died in prison. |- | "Old" Bill Wallace | 1926 | 1989 | 63 years | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | Imprisoned for shooting a man in an argument over a cigarette in a cafe of [[Melbourne]]. Died a month before his 108th birthday, still in prison, incarcerated in [[J Ward]]. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Walter H. Bourque Jr. | 1955 | ongoing | {{ayd|1955|12|11}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[New Hampshire]]. Serving a sentence of 99 years and six months for the axe murder of a four-year-old girl when he was 17. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Warren Nutter | 1956 | ongoing | {{ayd|1956|2|10}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Youngest man ever sentenced to death in [[Iowa]], when he was 18 years old, for the murder of a patrolman during a gas station robbery. Sentence commuted to life in prison in 1957.{{cite web|url=http://flashbak.com/death-row-stories-life-in-the-iowa-state-penitentiary-at-fort-madison-1956-47697/|title=Death Row Stories: Life In The Iowa State Penitentiary At Fort Madison (1956) -|publisher=}} |- | Hugh Alderman | 1917 | 1980 | 62 years, 192 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Florida]]. Escaped twice in 1919 and 1924. Moved to a mental hospital in 1927, where he died in 1980, aged 86. |- | [[Howard Unruh]] | 1949 | 2009 | 60 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Mass murderer]] who killed 13 people and injured three in [[Camden, New Jersey]]. Recluded in a mental hospital without trial or conviction. |} ==Prisoners who served between fifty and sixty years== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- | Raymond L. Shuman | 13 June 1958 | 3 February 2018https://www.ktnv.com/news/inmate-who-has-been-behind-bars-for-60-years-dies-in-carson-city | 59 years, 7 months, 20 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Nevada]]. Jailed for the murder and robbery of two men while he and his partner (who was the one that pulled the trigger) were [[AWOL]] from the [[US Navy]]. Set another prisoner on fire in 1973 due to a dispute about leaving a window open. Died in 2018. |- | [[Jesse Pomeroy]] | December 1874 | September 29, 1932 | 57 years, nine months | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Teenage [[serial killer]] nicknamed "The Boy Fiend", who tortured nine younger children and killed two in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. Sentenced to death when he was fifteen years old, this was changed to life in solitary confinement after two consecutive governors refused to sign his death warrant. The solitary confinement was lifted in 1917, and he died in 1932, still in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Chester Weger | 4 April 1961 | ongoing | {{ayd|1961|4|4}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Convicted for the murder of three women in [[Starved Rock State Park]] in 1960. Last denied parole in November 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.newstrib.com/free/weger-narrowly-denied-parole/article_b9dfcbc4-cb17-11e7-a3df-631e19a02e4a.html |title=Weger narrowly denied parole |first=Tom|last=Collins|publisher=La Salle (Illinois) News Tribune}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Booker T. Hillery | 1962 | ongoing | {{ayd|1962|11|01}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[California]]. Originally sentenced to death but changed to life in prison in the 1970s. [[Vasquez v. Hillery|Appealed]], was retried and found guilty again in 1986. |- | [[Mehmet VI]] | 1861 | 1918 | 56 years | {{Hs|Ottoman Empire}} {{flagcountry|Ottoman Empire}} | Kept in the [[Seraglio]] and the [[Kafes]] from his birth to his accession to the throne, aged 56. He was both the last Ottoman prince to be ritually imprisoned by his family and the one who was imprisoned for the longest time. |- | Joe Carr | 1941 | 1997 | 56 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Kansas]]. Convicted of murder for strangling a newborn and tossing his body in the [[Arkansas river]]. Carr refused to apply for parole until he was released, aged 79. |- | William Holly Griffith | 1915 | 1971 | 55 years, 359 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[West Virginia]], known as "the bestial killer" and the "leading bad man" in the state. Sentenced to life for murdering the sheriff that was going to arrest him and a railway policeman during his escape to [[Ohio]], where he was arrested. Tried to flee prison several times, the last one when he was already suffering from [[cancer]]. Died in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Hans-Georg Neumann]] | 1963 | ongoing | {{ayd|1963|5|30}} | {{Hs|GER}} {{flagcountry|GER}} | Abducted and shot a young couple at a lovers lane. Longest serving prisoner in Germany. |- | [[John Straffen]] | 1952 | 2007 | 55 years | {{Hs|UK}} {{flagcountry|UK}} | Multiple child killer. Sentenced to death for his third murder, which took place after he escaped from a mental hospital; the sentence was commuted to life in prison. Longest-serving prisoner in the United Kingdom at the time of his death. |- | Frank Wetzel | 1957 | 2012 | 55 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to two life sentences for the murders of two highway patrolmen when he was driving to [[Mississippi (state)|Mississippi]] to break his brother out of [[death row]]. His brother was executed two months later. Wetzel died of [[Alzheimer's disease]] when he was 90 years old, still in prison.{{cite web|url=http://northiowatoday.com/2012/07/23/frank-wetzel-90-n-c-%e2%80%99s-oldest-prisoner-dies/|title=Frank Wetzel, 90, N.C.’s oldest prisoner, dies|date=23 July 2012|publisher=}} |- | [[András Toma]] | 1945 | 2000 | 55 years | {{Hs|USSR}} {{flagcountry|USSR}}
{{Hs|RUS}} {{flagcountry|RUS}} | Believed to be the last [[POW]] of [[World War II]]. Toma, a Hungarian soldier, was captured in southern [[Poland]] in 1945 and later interned in a mental hospital of rural [[Kotelnich]], in Russia. His documents were lost and he was listed as [[killed in action|KIA]] by the [[Hungarian Army]]. He was returned to Hungary after a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] linguist realized that he spoke an eastern dialect of the [[Hungarian language]]. Died in 2004, aged 79. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Leotha Brown | 1964 | ongoing | {{ayd|1964|1|1}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Louisiana]]. |- | Garold Rheinschmidt | 1960 | May 1, 2015 | 54 years, eight months, 12 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Wisconsin]] at the time of his death.https://betweenthebars.org/posts/25139/the-longest-serving-wisconsin-prisoner-has-died |- | Tony Rawlins | 28 December 1955 | 17 April 2010 | 54 years, three months, 20 days | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | Convicted of the "Kissing Point mutilation murder", the strangling of a 12-year-old girl who rejected his advances. Was Australia's longest serving prisoner when he died, with eighteen parole applications being rejected. |- | Willie Gaines Smith | 1960 | 2014 | 54 years, 105 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Kentucky]]. Rejected parole because no nursing home accepted him and he would receive better medical care in prison. Died at the age of 76, still incarcerated. |- | [[:es:Don Diego de Castilla y Sandoval|Don Diego de Castilla y Sandoval]] | 1370 | 1424 | 54 years | {{Hs|Castile}} {{flagcountry|Castile}} | [[Posthumous child|Posthumous]] illegitimate child of [[Peter I of Castile]]. Recluded in [[Curiel de Duero|Curiel castle]] when he was an infant, under orders of [[Henry II of Castile|Henry II]]. Freed after his daughter, fathered with the castle warden's daughter, solicited his release to [[John II of Castile|John II]]. Died in [[Coca, Segovia|Coca]] in 1459, aged 89.{{cite web|url=http://castilla.maxerco.es/getperson.php?personID=I1340&tree=Fernandodecastilla|title=Diego de CASTILLA Y SANDOVAL b. 1370 d. 1458 Coca: Tabla de Parentescos de don Fernando de Castilla|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.euskalnet.net/laviana/gen_hispanas/castillaportugal.html|title=Pagina nueva 1|publisher=}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Sheldry Topp | 1963 | ongoing | 54 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Oldest juvenile lifer in [[Michigan]]. Last denied parole in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/oakland/2016/07/23/sheldry-topp-juvenile-parole-michigan/87472384/|title=Prosecutor: No sentencing break for Michigan's oldest juvenile lifer|publisher=}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | James R. Moore | 1963 | ongoing | 54 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Pled guilty to the rape and murder of a fourteen-year-old girl to avoid the death penalty and was sentenced to "natural life." Last parole application rejected in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2016/08/31/man-convicted-1962-murder-denied-parole-18th-time/89673924/|title=Parole denied 18th time in brutal 1962 murder/rape|publisher=}} |- | [[Machal Lalung]] | 1951 | 2005 | 54 years | {{Hs|IND}} {{flagcountry|IND}} | Originally arrested for "causing grievous harm," Lalung was interned in a psychiatric hospital until he was declared "fully fit" in 1967. However, he was mistakenly transferred to prison rather than released, and forgotten about until 2005. He was released without ever being tried or convicted, aged 77.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2005/08/indi-a26.html|title=Fifty-four years in jail without trial: the plight of prison inmates in India - World Socialist Web Site|first=Parwini|last=Zora|publisher=}} |- | [[Robert Stroud]] | 1909 | 1963 | 54 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Known as "the Birdman of [[Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary|Alcatraz]]" for the research on bird diseases that he conducted alone in his cell, although he actually did it at [[Leavenworth Penitentiary]] before he was moved to the federal prison in [[Alcatraz Island]]. |- | Harvey Stewart | 1958 | 2011 or 2012 | 53 or 54 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Paroled after serving a combined time of 60 years for various sentences in [[Texas]]. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Jerry Lee Hansen | 1965 | ongoing | {{ayd|1965|5|20}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Nebraska]]. Jailed for the murder of his parents in law and the attempted murder of his then wife. Disarmed a corrections officer and shot his ex-wife a second time in 1973, paralyzing her. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Antonio "Tony" Wheat | 1965 | ongoing | {{ayd|1965|11|1}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Washington state]]. Next parole hearing in 2020. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Richard Robles | 1965 | ongoing | {{ayd|1965|12|1}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Perpetrator of the [[Career Girls Murders]]. |- | [[Peter Woodcock]] | 1957 | 2010 | 52 years, 328 days | {{Hs|CAN}} {{flagcountry|CAN}} | Declared [[not guilty by reason of insanity]] and recluded in a mental hospital for the murder of three young children. Murdered a fellow patient in 1991. Died in 2010, still interned. |- | [[William MacDonald (serial killer)|William MacDonald]] | May 1963 | May 12, 2015 | 52 years | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | English-born Australian Serial killer known as "the [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]] Mutilator." Oldest and longest serving prisoner in [[New South Wales]] at the time of his death. |- | Jimmy Ennis | November 9, 1964 | 2016 | 52 years | {{Hs|Ireland}} {{flagcountry|Ireland}} | Longest held prisoner in Ireland. Sentenced to life in prison for fatally bludgeoning a farmer in [[County Cork]] following a dispute. He had just finished a prison term for attacking a woman with a hatchet.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/jimmy-ennis-irelands-longest-serving-prisoner-2290636-Jan2016/|title=When life means life: ‘I’m sorry for what I did to your mother and father’|first=Christina|last=Finn|publisher=}} He refused to apply for release until he was freed in 2016, aged 87.https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/a-lifetime-behind-bars-the-killers-who-are-our-longestserving-prisoners-36741405.html |- | Winston Moseley | 1964 | 2016 | 51 years, 291 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Murderer of [[Kitty Genovese]]. Died in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Walter Kelbach | 1967 | ongoing | {{ayd|1967|5|8}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Spree killer]] who murdered five people and raped two in [[Utah]] with his cousin. |- | Ian Brady | 1966 | 2017 | 51 years, 10 days | {{Hs|UK}} {{flagcountry|UK}} | Perpetrator of the [[Moors murders]] together with his girlfriend, Myra Hindley, who died in prison in 2002. Longest serving prisoner in the United Kingdom at the time of his death. |- | Alfred Tai | 1963 | 2014 | 51 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Hawaii]]. Paroled at the age of 72. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Alfred Vincent | 1968 | ongoing | {{ayd|1968|8|1}} | {{Hs|NZ}} {{flagcountry|NZ}} | Man held in preventive prison for the longest time in the world: sentence was imposed for assaulting five boys. Suspected of having molested between 200-500 children.{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/crime/76020376/new-zealands-longest-serving-prisoner-alfred-vincent-appeals-to-privy-council|title=New Zealand's longest serving prisoner Alfred Vincent appeals to Privy Council|publisher=}} |- | [[San Quentin Six|Hugo Pinell]] | 1965 | 2015 | 50 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Nicaragua]]n national sentenced to life in prison for rape. See below. |- | John Weber | 1926 | 1976 | 50 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Originally an immigrant from [[Austria-Hungary]], Weber was sentenced to life in prison without parole for the fatal shooting of his 18-month old daughter, which he served in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]]' [[Ohio Penitentiary]]. In 1972, [[List of governors of Ohio|Governor]] [[John J. Gilligan]] commuted his sentence to murder in the second degree. This made him eligible for parole, but he never benefitted from it. Was the oldest prisoner in the United States at the time of his death, only a few months from his 100th birthday.[https://books.google.es/books?id=EFsDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13&dq=%22oldest+prisoner%22&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3g6PFuuPTAhVsB8AKHV5HC4cQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=%22oldest%20prisoner%22&f=false ''Jet''. 24 October, 1974]Meyers, D. & Meyers, E. (2009). ''Central Ohio's Historic Prisons''. Arcadia Publishing, 127 pages. |} == Prisoners who served less than fifty years, but notable for other reasons == {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Sirhan Sirhan]] | 17 April 1969 | ongoing | {{ayd|1969|4|17}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Palestinian with Jordanian citizenship. Assassin of [[Robert F. Kennedy]]. Originally sentenced to death, sentence commuted in 1971 to life in prison. Parole has been denied fifteen times. |- | [[Heinrich Pommerenke]] | 10 June 1959 | 27 December 2008 | 49 years, six months, 17 days | {{Hs|GER}} {{flagcountry|GER}} | Serial killer known as "the Monster of the [[Black Forest]]." Was Germany's longest serving prisoner when he died. |- | Søren Mathiasen | 1876 | 1925 | 49 years, 180 days | {{Hs|DEN}} {{flagcountry|DEN}} | Farmer sentenced to life of hard labor in Horsens State Prison for killing the moneylender he was indebted to. Paroled. |- | Betty Smithey | 1963 | 2012 | 49 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving female prisoner in the United States at the time of her parole. |- | "Crazy Jimmie" Williams | 1948 | 1998 | 49 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Arizona]] at the time of his death, aged 66. |- | Melvin Thomas Mott | 5 March 1965 | 19 February 2014 | 48 years, 11 months, 14 days | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | Originally sentenced to two and a half years for child sex offences and escaping from custody, he was convicted of the 1964 murder of a 13-year-old girl in 1968 and sentenced to life imprisonment. Longest serving prisoner in Queensland when he died, having had 14 parole applications rejected. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Carlos Eduardo Robledo Puch]] | 1972 | ongoing | {{ayd|1972|2|4}} | {{Hs|ARG}} {{flagcountry|ARG}} | Serial killer. Longest serving prisoner in [[South America]] |- | [[Rudolf Hess]] | 10 May 1941 | 17 August 1987 | 46 years, 3 months, 7 days | {{Hs|UK}} {{flagcountry|UK}}
{{Hs|West Germany}} {{flagcountry|West Germany}} | [[Deputy Führer]] of [[Nazi Germany]] who flew solo to [[Scotland]] to negotiate a peace treaty but was instead taken prisoner. He was later tried for "crimes against peace" and sentenced to life in prison, which he served in [[Spandau Prison|Spandau]]. Committed suicide. |- | [[Joanna I of Castile]] | 1509 | 1555 | 46 years | {{Hs|Castile}} {{flagcountry|Castile}}
{{Hs|Spain}} [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|23px]] [[Habsburg Spain|Spain]] | Recluded in a [[nunnery]] of [[Tordesillas]] until her death, following orders of her father [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]]. |- | [[Walerian Łukasiński]] | 1822 | 1868 | 46 years | [[File:Military_ensign_of_Vistula_Flotilla_of_Congress_Poland.svg|23px]] [[Congress Poland]]
{{Hs|Russian Empire}} {{flagcountry|Russian Empire}} | Polish military officer suspected of harboring anti-Russian sentiments, kept in prison even after completing his original sentence of 14 years. Sentence spent entirely in [[solitary confinement]]. |- | [[:it:Vincenzo Verzeni|Vincenzo Verzeni]] | 1872 | 1918 | 46 years | {{Hs|Italy}} {{flagcountry|Kingdom of Italy}} | Double murderer and [[cannibal]]. |- | [[Iwao Hakamada]] | 1968 | 2014 | 46 years | {{Hs|Japan}} {{flagcountry|Japan}} | Spent entirely in [[death row]]. See below. |- | [[Amy Archer-Gilligan]] | 1917 | 1962 | 45 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Nursing home]] proprietor who poisoned her two husbands and a number of her tenants to cash on their life insurance. Originally sentenced to death, the sentence was changed to life in prison after a retrial in 1919. Served her sentence in a mental hospital from 1924 to her death. |- | [[Clarence Carnes]] | 1943 | 1988 | 45 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Originally sentenced to life in prison for murder when he was sixteen years old, he was sent to [[Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary]] in 1945 after two unsuccessful escape attempts. He took part in the "[[Battle of Alcatraz]]" the following year, but was recaptured and was sentenced to a further 203 years in prison. He was granted parole in 1973, but it was revoked twice before he died in prison from [[AIDS]]-related complications. |- | Kim Sŏn-myŏng | 1951 | 1995 | 45 years | {{Hs|South Korea}} {{flagcountry|South Korea}} | Longest held of the "[[unconverted long-term prisoners]]," [[North Korea]]n POWs captured during the [[Korean War]] who refused to renounce [[Juche]]. Kim Sŏn-myŏng was born in the south but joined the north, and was sentenced to death. The sentence was later commuted to life in prison; his family denounced him and had him declared dead in 1975. Released to North Korea. |- | [[Angola Three|Albert Woodfox]] | 1971 | 2016 | 45 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Black Panther Party|Black Panther]] imprisoned for robbery and later put in solitary confinement for the murder of a prison guard in 1972. See below. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Juan Corona]] | 1973 | ongoing | 45 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Mexico|Mexican]] serial killer nicknamed "the [[Machete]] Murderer", who killed 25 [[migrant farm worker]]s and buried them in fruit orchards of [[northern California]]. |- | [[Magdelaine Chapelain]] | 1679 | 1724 | 44 years, six months | {{Hs|Kingdom of France}} {{flagcountry|Kingdom of France}} | [[Paris]]ian fortune-teller involved in the [[Affair of the Poisons]]. Died in prison. |- | [[Pietro Acciarito]] | 1897 | 1941 | 44 years | {{Hs|Italy}} {{flagcountry|Kingdom of Italy}} | [[:it:Pietro Acciarito|Attempted assassin]] of [[Umberto I of Italy]]. Sentence spent entirely in solitary confinement. |- | [[Sharon Wiggins]] | 1969 | 2013 | 44 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest juvenile female serving life without parole. After fatal bank robbery, she was sentenced to death at 17 years old. Three years later, commuted to life without parole. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Sundiata Acoli]] | 1974 | ongoing | 44 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Former [[Black Panther Party]] finance minister and [[Black Liberation Army]] member sentenced to life plus 30 years for the murder of a [[State Trooper]] during a shootout at the [[New Jersey Turnpike]]. Acoli was accompanied by Zayd Shakur, who was killed in the shooting, and [[Assata Shakur]] who was also imprisoned for the murder but escaped from prison in 1979 and was granted [[political asylum]] in [[Cuba]]. |} ==Longest spells in solitary confinement== The sentence duration refers to the time spent in [[solitary confinement]], regardless of time spent in normal prison before or after. Death row prisoners, who are usually also held in isolation, are not included. {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- | [[Walerian Łukasiński]] | 1822 | 1868 | 46 years | [[File:Military_ensign_of_Vistula_Flotilla_of_Congress_Poland.svg|23px]] [[Congress Poland]]
{{Hs|Russian Empire}} {{flagcountry|Russian Empire}} | See above. |- | [[San Quentin Six#Hugo Pinell|Hugo Pinell]] | 1969 | 2015 | 46 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Murdered by another inmate during a riot two weeks after his solitary confinement was lifted. |- | [[Pietro Acciarito]] | 1897 | 1941 | 44 years | {{Hs|Italy}} {{flagcountry|Kingdom of Italy}} | See above. |- | [[Angola Three|Albert Woodfox]] | 1972 | 2016 | 44 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Placed in solitary confinement for the murder of a corrections officer. Released in 2016. |- | [[Robert Stroud]] | 1916 | 1959 | 42 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Imposed for murdering a prison guard in [[McNeil Island]]. |- | [[Jesse Pomeroy]] | 1875 | 1917 | 41 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | See above. |- | [[Woo Yong-gak]] | 1958 | 1999 | 41 years | {{Hs|South Korea}} {{flagcountry|South Korea}} | Captured during a North Korean commando raid after the armistice. Released to North Korea in 2000. |- | [[Angola Three|Herman Wallace]] | 1972 | 2013 | 41 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Placed in solitary confinement for the murder of the same corrections officer as Woodfox. Released in 2013, when he had advanced [[liver cancer]], but re-indicted two days later. Died the next day before he could be arrested. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Mark David Chapman]] | 1981 | ongoing | 37 years | {{Hs|US}} {{flagcountry|US}} | Placed in solitary confinement after pleading guilty to murdering [[John Lennon]] on December 8, 1980. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Thomas Silverstein]] | 1983 | ongoing | {{ayd|1983|10|22}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Called "America's most isolated man." Placed in solitary confinement for the murder of two inmates and a guard during a prison riot. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Robert Maudsley]] | 1983 | ongoing | 34+ years | {{Hs|UK}} {{flagcountry|UK}} | Serial killer imprisoned in 1977. Placed in a specially-built solitary cell after killing three other prisoners. |- | [[Darya Nikolayevna Saltykova]] | 1768 | 1801 | 33 years | {{Hs|Russian Empire}} {{flagcountry|Russian Empire}} | Countess convicted of killing 38 female serfs by beating and torturing them to death. Imprisoned at [[Ivanovsky Convent]] in [[Moscow]]; for the first 11 years, she was chained in a basement dungeon without a window and only given a candle during meals.https://russiapedia.rt.com/prominent-russians/history-and-mythology/darya-saltykova/ |- | rowspan="2"|[[Man in the Iron Mask]] | 1669? | 1675 | rowspan="2"|c. 29 years | rowspan="2"|{{Hs|France}} {{flagcountry|Kingdom of France}} | rowspan="2"|A mysterious prisoner kept in a solitary cell with double doors (to mute conversations) and forced to wear a black velvet mask at all times, following direct orders of [[Louis XIV]]. Much debate exists about the identity of the prisoner (variously called Marchioly or Eustache Dauger) and the reason of his confinement. After his death, myths arised claiming that the prisoner wore a full-headed iron mask, rather than velvet, and that two [[Musketeers of the Guard]] were posted with orders to shoot him if he removed it. The solitary spell was interrupted between 1675 and 1680, when the man in the mask served the also imprisoned [[Nicholas Fouquet]], Marquis of Belle-Îlle as his [[valet]]. |- | 1680 | 1703 |- | [[Robert Hillary King]] | 1972 | 2001 | 29 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Placed in solitary confinement for the same murder as Woodfox and Wallace, until his original conviction was overturned. |- | [[Salvatore Riina|Salvatore "Totò" Riina]] | 1993 | 2017 | 24 years | {{Hs|Italy}} {{flagcountry|Italy}} | Reputed "[[capo dei capi|boss of bosses]]" of the [[Sicily|Sicilian]] [[maffia]], nicknamed "The Beast". Believed to have ordered over 150 murders in Italy. Died in prison, aged 87.http://www.news.com.au/world/europe/the-most-violent-and-feared-mafia-godfather-has-died/news-story/261b89475a0b948ab26ea931e5447966http://www.india.com/news/agencies/jailed-sicilian-mafia-boss-of-bosses-riina-to-stay-in-jail-2334107/ |- | Ian Manuel | 1993 | 2016 | 23 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Tried as an adult]] and sentenced to life for non-fatally shooting a woman during a robbery, when he was 13 years-old. His sentence was reduced after it was ruled that imprisoning minors who had not killed anyone for life was unconstitutional. Released.{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/humaninterest/sentenced-to-life-as-a-teen-prisoner-learning-to-swap-solitary-for-society/1094912|title=Sentenced to life as a teen, prisoner learning to swap solitary for society|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://wfla.com/2016/11/14/tampa-teen-who-shot-woman-in-face-in-1993-released-from-prison-early-with-help-from-his-victim/|title=Tampa teen who shot woman in face in 1993, released from prison with help from victim|first=|last=Candace McCowan|date=14 November 2016|publisher=}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Yolanda Saldívar]] | 1995 | ongoing | 23 years | {{Hs|US}} {{flagcountry|US}} | Found guilty of first-degree murder in the death of [[Tejano]] singer [[Selena Quintanilla-Pérez]] on March 31, 1995. Placed in solitary confinement after receiving numerous death threats from fellow inmates. |- | [[Leonora Christina Ulfeldt]] | 1663 | 1685 | 22 years | {{Hs|DEN}} {{flagcountry|DEN}} | Daughter of [[Christian IV of Denmark]]. Confined to a small cell in the [[Blåtårn|Blue Tower]] of [[Copenhagen Castle]] by her brother, [[Frederick III of Denmark|Frederick III]], accused of [[treason]]. Released after 22 years by [[Christian V of Denmark|Christian V]], she joined a convent where she died in 1698, aged 76. |- | [[Russell Melvin Shoats]] | 1992 | 2014 | 22 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Member of the Black Unity Council, [[Black Panther Party]] and [[Black Liberation Army]], sentenced to life in prison without parole for the murder of a police officer. Shoats spent his time in solitary in a 7-by-12 foot cell, always illuminated by lights, for 23 or 24 hours a day. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Luis Felipe (murderer)|Luis Felipe]] | 1997https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/15/nyregion/seen-as-threat-gang-chief-gets-a-life-term-in-solitary.html | ongoing | {{ayd|1997|02|14}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Leader of the New York chapter of the [[Latin Kings (gang)|Latin Kings]]. Convicted and placed in solitary confinement for ordering several murders when he was already in prison for other offenses. |- | [[Rudolf Hess]] | 1966 | 1987 | 21 years | {{Hs|West Germany}} {{flagcountry|West Germany}} | Became the only prisoner in [[Spandau Prison]] after all the others completed their sentences or were pardoned. |- | [[Clayton Fountain]] | 1983 | 2004 | 21 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[US Marine Corps|Marine]] sentenced to life in prison for the murder of his staff sergeant in 1974, and placed in solitary after murdering three other prisoners and one corrections officer. Converted to [[Catholicism]] and was accepted as a lay brother of the [[Trappists|Trappist monks]] posthumously. |- | [[Giovanni Passannante]] | 1879 | 1899 | 20 years | {{Hs|Kingdom of Italy}} {{flagcountry|Kingdom of Italy}} | Attempted assassin of Umberto I of Italy. Locked in a dark, small cell below sea level in [[Portoferraio]], [[Isle of Elba]]. His conditions became a scandal after they were revealed and he was moved to an asylum in [[Montelupo Fiorentino]], where he died in 1910. |- | [[John T. Downey]] | rowspan="2"|1952 | 1973 | 20 years, 3 months and 14 days | rowspan="2"|{{Hs|China}} {{flagcountry|China}} | rowspan="2"|[[CIA]] agents captured in [[Manchuria]] after their plane was shot down by Chinese forces during the [[Korean War]]; the mission was part of a failed attempt to establish an anti-Communist guerrilla in mainland China. Released after the thaw of [[Chinese-American relations]]. There was a three-week break in their solitary confinement in 1955, when they were allowed to interact with the crew of a downed American [[B-29]].http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/history/2014/09/john_t_downey_cia_agent_captured_by_china_during_the_korean_war_the_story.html |- | [[Richard Fecteau]] | 1971 | 19 years |- | [[Attempted assassination of Leonid Brezhnev#The would-be assassin|Viktor Ivanovich Ilyin]] | 1969 | 1988 | 19 years | {{Hs|USSR}} {{flagcountry|USSR}} | Attempted assassin of [[Leonid Brezhnev]]. Released in 1990. |- | [[Clarence Carnes]] | 1946 | 1963 | 17 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Placed in solitary for his part in the "Battle of Alcatraz". The measure ended with the closing of the prison. |- | [[Christopher Scarver]] | 1994 | 2010 | 16 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Placed in solitary confinement for the double murder of [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] and [[Jesse Anderson]]. All three men were serving life sentences for murder at the time of the crime. |} ==Longest spells in death row== These prisoners were [[death penalty|sentenced to death]] rather than prison, but their execution was stalled for a prolongued time due to different reasons. {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- | [[Iwao Hakamada]] | 1968 | 2014 | 46 years | {{Hs|Japan}} {{flagcountry|Japan}} | Granted a retrial and found innocent after it was determined that the evidence used to convict him the first time was forged. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Richard Gerald Jordan | 1977 | ongoing | {{ayd|1977|2|3}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to death for the abduction and murder of a woman in [[Mississippi (state)|Mississippi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/2015/07/29/ag-requests-august-execution-date-jordan/30823285/|title=AG requests August execution date for Richard Gerald Jordan|publisher=}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Raymond Riles]] | 1978 | ongoing | 39+ years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest held prisoner in death row in Texas. His execution was stayed several times since 1980, for different reasons. He was later diagnosed with mental problems and is as a result considered not mentally fit to be executed, but won't be moved out of death row either. |- | Gary Alvord | 1973 | 2013 | 39 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Schizophrenic]] sentenced to death in [[Florida]] for the murder of three women over the price of one game of pool. Died of a [[brain tumor]] after several delays. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Douglas Stankewitz | 1980 | ongoing | 38 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Oldest death row inmate at California's San Quentin State Prison, a member of the [[Mono people|Mono nation]] sentenced to death for the abduction and murder of a 22-year old woman. Retried twice and sentenced to death on both occasions.https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/nov/06/california-death-penalty-vote-douglas-stankewitzhttps://www.freechief.org/ |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Lawrence Bittaker]] | March 24, 1981 | ongoing | {{ayd|1981|3|24}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | One of the two "Toolbox Killers" who kidnapped, raped, tortured and murdered five teenage girls in southern California during a period of five months in 1979. Currently held in death row at San Quentin. His partner in crime, Roy Norris, was sentenced to life in prison with possibility of parole after 30 years in exchange for testifying againt Bittaker. |- | [[Sadamichi Hirasawa]] | 1950 | 1987 | 37 years | {{Hs|Japan}} {{flagcountry|Japan}} | Confessed under torture to have committed the Teikoku Bank Incident of 1948, a mass poisoning of Imperial Bank employees that killed ten people. Hirasawa was never executed because no Justice Minister wanted to sign his death warrant, as all believed that he had been falsely charged. However, he wasn't granted a retrial either, and he was still in death row when he died from [[pneumonia]] in 1987. |- | [[Brandon Astor Jones]] | 1979 | 2016 | 37 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to death for his involvement in the [[felony murder]] of a convenience store manager in [[Georgia (US state)|Georgia]]. Was retried and sentenced to death again in 1997 because the jurors at the first trial had brought a [[Bible]] into the deliberation room. Oldest prisoner in Georgia at the time of his execution, aged 72. |- |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Albert Greenwood Brown]] | February 3, 1982 | ongoing | {{ayd|1982|3|2}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Pedophile who abducted and murdered a 15-year-old on her way to school while being on parole for molesting another girl in California. Brown was scheduled for execution on September 30, 2010, but it was put on hold due to [[lethal injection]] supplies being [[Lethal injection#Complications of executions and cessation of supply of lethal injection drugs|unavailable]] at the time. |- | Tomiyama Tsuneki | 1967 | 2003 | 36 years | {{Hs|Japan}} {{flagcountry|Japan}} | Died of [[kidney failure]] in prison, at the age of 86.Close, P. & Askew, D. (2017). ''Asia Pacific and Human Rights: A global political economy perspective.'' Routledge, 240 pages. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Doug Clark]] | March 24, 1983 | ongoing | {{ayd|1983|3|24}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | One of the couple known as the "Sunset Strip Killers", who raped and murdered six women in Los Angeles during the summer of 1980. His partner, [[Carol M. Bundy]], died in prison in 2003. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Michael Morales]] | June 30, 1983 | ongoing | {{ayd|1983|06|30}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Raped and murdered a 17-year-old girl who was in a [[love triangle]] with Morales's cousin and another man in California; his cousin was sentenced to life in prison as inductor. Though Morales did not deny his guilt, doubts about the evidence presented in his trial mounted as his scheduled execution for February 26, 2006 came near. The execution was postponed indefinitely due to medical professionals refusing to participate in executions, as their presence is obligatory under California law. |- | [[Sakae Menda]] | 1949 | 1983 | 34 years | {{Hs|Japan}} {{flagcountry|Japan}} | After being arrested for stealing rice, Menda was tortured until he confessed to the murders of a [[Buddhist]] priest and his wife, which he did not commit. He was not represented by a lawyer, no physical evidence linking Menda to the murders was ever produced, and the testimony of witnesses backing his [[alibi]] was deliberatedly kept out of his trial. In 1979 he was granted a retrial and in 1983 he was acquitted, becoming the first person in the [[History of Japan]] to be released from death row. |- | Edward Harold Schad | 1979 | 2013 | 34 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Oldest prisoner in [[Arizona]] death row at the time of his execution by [[lethal injection]], aged 71. Sentenced to death for the murder and robbery of a 74-year-old man in 1978, while he was in parole for another murder ten years prior.https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/09/arizona-executes-schad-oldest-person-death-rowhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/edward-harold-schad-jr-oldest-ariz-death-row-inmate-executed-for-1978-murder/ |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Kevin Cooper (prisoner)|Kevin Cooper]] | 21 May, 1985 | ongoing | {{ayd|1985|5|21}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Career burglar sentenced to death for the murders of four members of the same family and attempted murder of two others during a home invasion in [[Chino Hills]], California in 1983, shortly after he escaped from prison. Cooper was scheduled for execution on February 10, 2004, but it was postponed to allow DNA testing of the crime scene and getaway vehicle that did not exist at the time of his conviction. The results of both tests supported the case against Cooper. |- | [[Jack Alderman]] | June 14, 1975 | September 16, 2008 | 33 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Murdered his wife with a wrench in Georgia. Executed by lethal injection. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Tiequon Cox]] | May 7, 1986 | ongoing | {{ayd|1986|05|07}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Member of the [[Crips]] sentenced to death for the hired [[mass murder]] of five relatives of former [[NFL]] player [[Kermit Alexander]] in their home. Cox was 18 at the time of the crimes. |- | Robert Brian Waterhouse | 1980 | 2012 | 32 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Murdered and mutilated a woman in Florida while he was on parole from a life sentence for murder.http://www.clarkprosecutor.org/html/death/US/waterhouse1281.htm |- | Henry McCollum | 1983 | 2014 | 31 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving death row inmate in North Carolina. Sentenced for the rape and murder of a 11-year-old girl, while his half-brother was sentenced to life in prison. Both men were exonerated by DNA and released.{{cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/184899-north-carolina-death-row-exoneration/|title=DNA clears N. Carolina’s longest-serving death row inmate & his half-brother|publisher=}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[David Carpenter]] | May 10, 1988 | ongoing | {{ayd|1988|5|10}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Known as the "Trailside Killer", killed at least ten hikers and attacked another one in state parks near [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]]. He was attributed a 1979 murder after a DNA match in December 2009. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Ronald Gray]] | June 29, 1988 | ongoing | {{ayd|1988|6|29}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Convict held for the longest time ever on the [[US Military]] death row, a serial rapist and murderer who committed his crimes while stationed in [[Fort Bragg (North Carolina)|Fort Bragg]] as a member of the [[82nd Airborne Division (United States)|82nd Airborne Division]]. |} ==See also== *[[List of longest prison sentences]] *[[List of prisoners with whole-life tariffs]] *[[Blanche Monnier]], a French woman who was locked alone in a small room by her own family for 25 years ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Other sources== * {{Citation | url =http://mikedashhistory.com/2010/07/24/a-prison-curiosity// | title = The Longest Prison Sentences Ever Served | publisher = A Blast From the Past | date = 2010-07-24}}. Lists the lengthiest sentences actually completed, with detailed case studies. {{DEFAULTSORT:List of longest prison sentences served}} [[Category:Lists of prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment]] [[Category:Penal imprisonment]] [[Category:Life imprisonment]] [[Category:World records]]

page.title: List of mountains and hills of Japan by height

revision.comment: Added in Mt. Yake since it wasn't included: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Yake

page.title: List of mountains of Switzerland above 3000 m

revision.text:
{{Annotated image | image = Sciora.jpg | image-width = 380 | image-left = -3 | image-top = -80 | width = 360 | height = 160 | float = | annotations = | caption = The [[Sciora group]] ([[Bregaglia Range|Bregaglia Alps]]) }} {{GeoGroupTemplate}} This is a list of [[mountain]]s of [[Switzerland]] above {{convert|3000|m|ft|0}}. This height, in the [[Alps]], approximately corresponds to the level of the climatic [[snow line]]. For a list of mountains (major summits only) including lower summits, see [[List of mountains of Switzerland]]. This list only includes significant summits with a [[topographic prominence]] of at least {{convert|150|m|ft|0}}. There are 437 such summits exceeding 3,000 m in Switzerland. They are found in the [[Cantons of Switzerland|cantons]] of [[Valais]], [[Canton of Bern|Bern]], [[Graubünden]], [[Canton of Uri|Uri]], [[Canton of Glarus|Glarus]], [[Ticino]], [[Canton of St. Gallen|St. Gallen]], [[Obwalden]] and [[Vaud]].Christian Thöni, [http://www.gipfelverzeichnis.ch Directory of the mountains of Switzerland] All mountain heights and prominences on the list are from the largest-[[scale (map)|scale]] maps available.All mountain heights and prominences are from the 1:25,000 [[Swisstopo]] topographic maps. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ Distribution of the mountains with at least 150 metres of prominence |- !Canton!!3000-
3249m!!3250-
3499m!!3500-
3749m!!3750-
3999m!!4000-
4249m!!4250-
4499m!!4500m+!!Total (3000m+) |- |align=left|[[Canton of Bern|Bern]] |align=right|18 |align=right|13 |align=right|11 |align=right|7 |align=right|4 |align=right|1 |align=right|0 |align=right|54 |- |align=left|[[Canton of Glarus|Glarus]] |align=right|6 |align=right|2 |align=right|1 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|9 |- |align=left|[[Graubünden]] |align=right|165 |align=right|37 |align=right|4 |align=right|4 |align=right|1 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|211 |- |align=left|[[Obwalden]] |align=right|2 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|2 |- |align=left|[[Canton of St. Gallen|St. Gallen]] |align=right|2 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|2 |- |align=left|[[Ticino]] |align=right|16 |align=right|2 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|18 |- |align=left|[[Canton of Uri|Uri]] |align=right|22 |align=right|7 |align=right|3 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|32 |- |align=left|[[Valais]] |align=right|56 |align=right|27 |align=right|37 |align=right|30 |align=right|17 |align=right|6 |align=right|4 |align=right|177 |- |align=left|[[Vaud]] |align=right|3 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|0 |align=right|3 |- class="sortbottom" |align=left|'''Switzerland''' |align=right|'''246''' |align=right|'''79''' |align=right|'''48''' |align=right|'''35''' |align=right|'''19''' |align=right|'''6''' |align=right|'''4''' |align=right|'''437''' |} ==List== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center; background-color:#F9F9F9; font-size: 90%;" |- bgcolor="#dddddd" !Rank !Mountain !Height (m) ![[Topographic prominence|Drop]] (m) !Coordinates !Range !Canton(s) !FirstThe three main sources for first ascent data are:
For the Western Alps; [[W.A.B. Coolidge]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=df4OAAAAQAAJ The Alps in nature and history], Methuen & Co, London, 1908.
For the Central Alps; [[Gottlieb Studer]], ''Über Eis und Schnee: Die höchsten Gipfel der Schweiz und die Geschichte ihrer Besteigung,'' Volumes 1-3, Schmid & Francke, Bern, 1896-1899.
For the Eastern Alps: ''Die Erschließung der Ostalpen'', Volumes 1-3, German and Austrian Alpine Club, Berlin, 1894.
Given are the years for the first recorded ascents. In many cases local people or surveyors made earlier ascents. In particular, chamois and ibex hunters are expected to have reached many summits. Years in italics indicate that it is known that an earlier ascent was made, for example by the presence of artifacts on top or the summit's prior use as a triangulation point.

This is a '''list of rivers in [[Guatemala]]'''.
==By drainage basin== This list is arranged by [[drainage basin]], with respective tributaries indented under each larger stream's name.
===[[Gulf of Mexico]]=== *''Grijalva River (Mexico)'' **[[Usumacinta River]] ***[[San Pedro River (Guatemala)|San Pedro River]] ***''Lacantún River (Mexico)'' ****[[Xalbal River]] (Xaclbal River) ****[[Ixcán River]] ***[[Pasión River]] (Río de la Pasión) ****[[San Juan River (Guatemala)|San Juan River]] *****[[Poxte River]] ****[[Machaquila River]] ****[[Cancuén River]] ***[[Salinas River (Guatemala)|Salinas River]] **** [[Chixoy River]] (Río Negro) ***** [[Salamá River]] ****[[San Román River]] **[[Seleguá River]] ***[[Nentón River]] **[[Cuilco River]] ***[[Cabajchum River]] ****[[Tzalá River]] ***[[Las Manzanas River]] ****[[Blanco River (San Marcos)]]

{{short description|Definitions and examples of the interactions between the relatively mobile sections of the lithosphere}} {{further|plate tectonics}} {{One source|date=January 2016}}
[[Image:Tectonic plate boundaries.png|thumb|right|Three types of plate boundary.]] [[File:Continental-continental conservative plate boundary opposite directions.svg|thumb|Transform boundary]] [[File:Continental-continental constructive plate boundary.svg|thumb|Divergent boundary]] [[File:Continental-continental destructive plate boundary.svg|thumb|Convergent boundary]]
[[Tectonic plate]] interactions are of three different basic types:<ref>{{cite web|title=Tectonic Plates and Plate Boundaries|url=http://www.gns.cri.nz/Home/Learning/Science-Topics/Earthquakes/Earthquakes-at-a-Plate-Boundary/Tectonic-Plates-and-Plate-Boundaries|website=[[GNS Science]]|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> * '''[[Divergent boundary|Divergent boundaries]]''' are areas where plates move away from each other, forming either [[mid-oceanic ridge]]s or [[rift valley]]s. These are also known as constructive boundaries. * '''[[Convergent boundary|Convergent boundaries]]''' are areas where plates move toward each other and collide. These are also known as compressional or destructive boundaries. ** '''[[Subduction]] zones''' occur where an ''oceanic'' plate meets a ''continental'' plate and is pushed underneath it. Subduction zones are marked by [[oceanic trench]]es. The descending end of the oceanic plate melts and creates pressure in the [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]], causing [[volcano]]es to form. ** '''[[Obduction]]''' occurs when the ''continental'' plate is pushed under the ''oceanic'' plate, but this is unusual as the relative densities of the tectonic plates favours subduction of the ''oceanic'' plate. This causes the oceanic plate to buckle and usually results in a new mid ocean ridge forming and turning the obduction into subduction {{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} ** '''[[Orogeny|Orogenic belts]]''' occur where two continental plates collide and push upwards to form large [[mountain range]]s. These are also known as collision boundaries. * '''[[Transform boundary|Transform boundaries]]''' occur when two plates grind past each other with only limited convergent or divergent activity.
==Divergent boundaries== [[File:Plate tectonics map.gif|thumb|upright=1.4|right|Plate tectonics map]]
* The [[East African Rift]] (Great Rift Valley) in eastern Africa * The [[Mid-Atlantic Ridge]] system separates the [[North American Plate]] and [[South American Plate]] in the west from the [[Eurasian Plate]] and [[African Plate]] in the east * The [[Gakkel Ridge]] is a slow spreading ridge located in the [[Arctic Ocean]] * The [[East Pacific Rise]], extending from the South Pacific to the [[Gulf of California]] * The [[Baikal Rift Zone]] in eastern Russia * The [[Red Sea Rift]] * The [[Aden Ridge]] along the southern shore of the [[Arabian Peninsula]] * The [[Carlsberg Ridge]] in the eastern [[Indian Ocean]] * The [[Gorda Ridge]] off the northwest coast of North America * The [[Explorer Ridge]] off the northwest coast of North America * The [[Juan de Fuca Ridge]] off the northwest coast of North America * The [[Chile Rise]] off the southeast Pacific
==Convergent boundaries (subduction zone)== * The oceanic [[Nazca Plate]] [[subduction|subducts]] beneath the continental [[South American Plate]] at the [[Peru–Chile Trench]]. * Just north of the Nazca Plate, the oceanic [[Cocos Plate]] subducts under the [[Caribbean Plate]] and forms the [[Middle America Trench]]. * The [[Cascadia subduction zone]] is where the oceanic [[Juan de Fuca Plate|Juan de Fuca]], [[Gorda Plate|Gorda]] and [[Explorer Plate|Explorer]] Plates subduct under the continental North American plate. * The oceanic [[Pacific Plate]] subducts under the [[North American Plate]] (composed of both continental and oceanic sections) forming the [[Aleutian Trench]]. * The oceanic [[Pacific plate]] subducts beneath the continental [[Okhotsk Plate]] at the [[Japan Trench]]. * The oceanic [[Philippine Sea Plate]] subducts beneath the [[Eurasian Plate]] at the [[Ryukyu Trench]]. * The oceanic [[Pacific Plate]] subducts under the oceanic [[Philippine Sea Plate|Philippine Sea]] Plate forming the [[Mariana Trench]]. * The oceanic [[Philippine Sea Plate]] is subducting under the [[Philippine Mobile Belt]] forming the [[Philippine Trench]] and the [[East Luzon Trench]]. * The [[Eurasian Plate]] is subducting under the Philippine Mobile Belt at the [[Manila Trench]]. * The [[Sunda Plate]] is subducting under the Philippine Mobile Belt at the [[Negros Trench]] and the [[Cotobato Trench]]. * The oceanic [[Indo-Australian Plate]] is subducted beneath the continental [[Sunda Plate]] along the [[Sunda Trench]]. * The oceanic [[Pacific Plate]] is subducting under the Indo-Australian Plate north and east of New Zealand, but the direction of subduction reverses south of the [[Alpine Fault]] where the Indo-Australian Plate starts subducting under the Pacific Plate. *The [[South American Plate]] is subducting under the [[South Sandwich Plate]], forming the [[South Sandwich Trench]].
==Orogenic belts== {{Main|List of orogenies}} * The most dramatic orogenic belt on the planet is the one between the [[Indo-Australian Plate]] and [[African Plate]] on one side (to the South) and the [[Eurasian Plate]] on the other side (to the North). This belt runs from New Zealand in the East-SouthEast, through [[Indonesia]], along the [[Himalayas]], through the Middle East up to the Mediterranean in the West-Northwest. It is also called the "Tethyan" Zone, as it constitutes the zone along which the ancient Tethys Ocean was deformed and disappeared. The following mountain belts can be distinguished: ** The European [[Alps]] ** The [[Carpathians]] ** The [[Pyrenees]] ** The [[Apennines]] ** The [[Dinarides]] ** The North African mountain belts such as the [[Atlas Mountains]] ** The [[Kras Plateau|Karst Plateau]] of the Balkan Peninsula ** The [[Caucasus]] ** The [[Zagros]] ** The [[Himalayas]] ** The [[Geography of Indonesia|Indonesian Archipelago]] ** The [[Southern Alps of New Zealand]] *The [[Andes]] orogenic belt is the latest of a series of [[orogeny|orogenies]] along the western margin of the [[South American Plate]].
==Transform boundaries== * The [[San Andreas Fault]] in [[California]] is an active transform boundary. The Pacific Plate (carrying the city of [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]) is moving northwards with respect to the North American Plate. * The [[Queen Charlotte Fault]] on the [[Pacific Northwest]] coast of North America * The [[Motagua Fault]], which crosses through [[Guatemala]], is a transform boundary between the southern edge of the [[North American Plate]] and the northern edge of the [[Caribbean Plate]]. * New Zealand's [[Alpine Fault]] is another active transform boundary. * The [[Dead Sea Transform]] (DST) fault which runs through the [[Jordan River]] Valley in the Middle East. * The [[Owen Fracture Zone]] along the southeastern boundary of the [[Arabian Plate]].
==See also== *{{annotated link|Triple junction}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Plate tectonics|*]]
